defs.docs: A thread pool to execute scheduled actions in parallel.

attributes.value: / A thread pool to execute scheduled actions in parallel.
/ While a normal thread pool is only able to execute actions as soon as
/ possible, a scheduled thread pool can execute actions after a specific
/ delay, or excecute actions periodically.
warn(missing_docs)

defs.name: JobHandle
defs.docs: A handle to a scheduled job.

attributes.value: / A handle to a scheduled job.
/ Cancels the job.

defs.name: ScheduledThreadPool
defs.docs: A pool of threads which can run tasks at specific time intervals.

attributes.value: / A pool of threads which can run tasks at specific time intervals.
/ When the pool drops, all pending scheduled executions will be run, but
/ periodic actions will not be rescheduled after that.

defs.name: new
defs.docs: Creates a new thread pool with the specified number of threads.

attributes.value: / Creates a new thread pool with the specified number of threads.
/ # Panics
/ Panics if `num_threads` is 0.

defs.name: with_name
defs.docs:
Creates a new thread pool with the specified number of threads which
 will be named.

attributes.value: / Creates a new thread pool with the specified number of threads which
/ will be named.
/ The substring `{}` in the name will be replaced with an integer
/ identifier of the thread.
/ # Panics
/ Panics if `num_threads` is 0.

defs.name: execute
defs.value:
pub fn execute<F>(&Self, F) -> JobHandle where F: FnOnce() -> () + Send +
'static
defs.docs: Executes a closure as soon as possible in the pool.

attributes.value: / Executes a closure as soon as possible in the pool.

defs.name: execute_after
defs.value:
pub fn execute_after<F>(&Self, Duration, F) -> JobHandle where F: FnOnce() ->
() + Send + 'static
defs.docs: Executes a closure after a time delay in the pool.

attributes.value: / Executes a closure after a time delay in the pool.

defs.name: execute_at_fixed_rate
defs.value:
pub fn execute_at_fixed_rate<F>(&Self, Duration, Duration, F) -> JobHandle
where F: FnMut() -> () + Send + 'static
defs.docs: Executes a closure after an initial delay at a fixed rate in the pool.

attributes.value: / Executes a closure after an initial delay at a fixed rate in the pool.
/ The rate includes the time spent running the closure. For example, if
/ the rate is 5 seconds and the closure takes 2 seconds to run, the
/ closure will be run again 3 seconds after it completes.
/ # Panics
/ If the closure panics, it will not be run again.

defs.name: execute_at_dynamic_rate
defs.value:
pub fn execute_at_dynamic_rate<F>(&Self, Duration, F) -> JobHandle where
F: FnMut() -> Option<Duration> + Send + 'static
defs.docs: Executes a closure after an initial delay at a dynamic rate in the pool.

attributes.value: / Executes a closure after an initial delay at a dynamic rate in the pool.
/ The rate includes the time spent running the closure. For example, if
/ the return rate is 5 seconds and the closure takes 2 seconds to run, the
/ closure will be run again 3 seconds after it completes.
/ # Panics
/ If the closure panics, it will not be run again.

defs.name: execute_with_fixed_delay
defs.value:
pub fn execute_with_fixed_delay<F>(&Self, Duration, Duration, F) -> JobHandle
where F: FnMut() -> () + Send + 'static
defs.docs: Executes a closure after an initial delay at a fixed rate in the pool.

attributes.value: / Executes a closure after an initial delay at a fixed rate in the pool.
/ In contrast to `execute_at_fixed_rate`, the execution time of the
/ closure is not subtracted from the delay before it runs again. For
/ example, if the delay is 5 seconds and the closure takes 2 seconds to
/ run, the closure will run again 5 seconds after it completes.
/ # Panics
/ If the closure panics, it will not be run again.

defs.name: execute_with_dynamic_delay
defs.value:
pub fn execute_with_dynamic_delay<F>(&Self, Duration, F) -> JobHandle where
F: FnMut() -> Option<Duration> + Send + 'static
defs.docs: Executes a closure after an initial delay at a dynamic rate in the pool.

attributes.value: / Executes a closure after an initial delay at a dynamic rate in the pool.
/ In contrast to `execute_at_dynamic_rate`, the execution time of the
/ closure is not subtracted from the returned delay before it runs again. For
/ example, if the delay is 5 seconds and the closure takes 2 seconds to
/ run, the closure will run again 5 seconds after it completes.
/ # Panics
/ If the closure panics, it will not be run again.
